node.title: Open imaging data for biology
node.body: The Image Data Resource: prototype of the first open, online repository linking imaging and molecular data
node.field_meta_keywords: imaging, EuroBioImaging, Alvis Brazma, big data

field_image.alt: Revathi Nathaniel, UX expert at EMBL-EBI

node.title: UX toolkit aids industry R&D
node.body: User Experience designers rarely specialise in the life sciences – EMBL-EBI and the Pistoia Alliance look to fill the gap

node.title: Human Cell Atlas data platform kicks off with support from CZI
node.body: EMBL-EBI, the Broad Institute and UCSC Genomics Institute will partner in developing a data coordination platform for the Human Cell Atlas, supported by CZI
node.field_meta_keywords: Human Cell Atlas, John Marioni, single-cell sequencing, RNAseq, CZI, Chan Zuckerberg, Grants, major collaborations, Data Coordination Platform

field_image.alt: Protein Data Bank in Europe logo

node.title: SIFT-ing through sequence space in the PDB
node.body: The new, improved SIFTS service offers more targeted cross referencing. For example, it maps molecular structures in PDBe to the most appropriate isoform within a UniProt accession.
node.field_meta_keywords: protein complexes, SIFTS, PDBe, Sameer Valenkar

node.title: RNAcentral Release 7
node.body: The latest version of the RNAcentral database is now available.

node.title: Omics Discovery Index boosts FAIR data sharing
node.body: A global index led by EMBL-EBI emerges as the ‘PubMed Central of life-science datasets’

node.title: HipSci: The human stem cell bank of tomorrow
node.body: UK’s largest resource of human stem cells from healthy donors unveiled
node.field_meta_keywords: HipSci, stem cells, iPSC, Oliver Stegle, Stegle

node.title: EVA issues long-term IDs for non-human variants
node.body: dbSNP and EVA to share responsibility for maintaining reliable, long-term accession numbers for genetic variation data
node.field_meta_keywords: EVA, Thomas Keane, NCBI, genetic variation, accession numbers, partnerships

node.title: New releases: InterPro 63.0 and InterProScan 5.24-63.0
node.body: New releases: InterPro database (version 63.0) and InterProScan (5.24-63.0) for functional analysis. InterPro now covers over 80.5% of the UniProt Knowledgebase and predicts GO terms for over 50 million proteins.
node.field_meta_keywords: Protein families, InterProScan, InterPro, Protein, protein family, protein motif
